title: It’s Crunch Time for Netflix and These 5 Other Stocks
text:
Text size

Company earnings won’t begin pouring in for another week, but I’m ready now. The theme this reporting season is “Let’s get this over with.” Or maybe it’s “Anything but more macro stuff.”

On the whole, the numbers won’t be good, but they’ll be better than predicted. Analysts polled by FactSet say earnings per share for S&P 500 companies will fall 4.1% from the level a year ago. Most analysts follow the Showcase Showdown rule from The Price Is Right—guess as close as you can, but don’t go over—so companies tend to beat estimates. Expect earnings to end up about flat for the quarter.

Then comparisons get easier. By next year, Wall Street says earnings will jump 10%. I’m giving that only half a hallelujah for now, and keeping the other half in escrow. With distant forecasts, analysts often start way too high, then slash their numbers to beatable levels closer to reporting time. Figure 5% growth next year. Anything higher, and I’ll owe you a -lujah.

All depends on the economy, of course. This past week, one key report showed trouble for manufacturing, and stocks tanked for two days. Then jobs came in good enough, and stocks jumped. In the background, odds ended the week higher that the Federal Reserve will again cut interest rates. But UBS says that cutting rates from here could hurt stocks, rather than help them.

See what I mean about macro reports being a chore? I lose track of whether bad news is still good news, and if so, whether there has been so much of that kind of good news that it has reversed polarity to become bad news. Give me a few weeks of company results to clear my head. I’ll watch the bellwether companies dutifully, but more interesting are the high-drama names that tend to move a lot around reporting time.

Start with Netflix (ticker: NFLX). The company missed subscriber forecasts last quarter, causing shares to fall 10% in a day. They peaked above $400 last year and recently traded at $272. Investors have been losing patience with young companies burning cash; Netflix is a not-so-young company doing so. But it has also reshaped the media business, and long defied bears. It reports third-quarter results Oct. 16, and Bank of America Merrill Lynch calls it a make-or-break quarter. If subs don’t shine, it’s hard to imagine the path will get easier after Disney+ launches in November and other well-financed streaming services follow.

Next, toys. Mattel (MAT) and Hasbro (HAS) both report later in October. Last quarter, their stocks jumped 13% and 10%, respectively, after both beat estimates, but the similarities end there. Hasbro is up 113% over the past five years, and Mattel has plunged 65%. It was about five years ago that Hasbro stripped Mattel of a massive licensing deal with Disney for princess dolls. Mattel has also struggled with Barbie falling out of favor. The brand could get snowed out this Christmas by Disney’s Frozen 2, a film that hits theaters in late November and could be a real doll-mover for Hasbro.

More important for Mattel is what Jefferies analyst Stephanie Wissink calls a “hyper binary event.” The company canceled a much-needed bond sale over an anonymous whistle-blower letter, but hasn’t detailed the complaint. If it does so soon, and the matter isn’t serious, its shares could gain 10% to 15%, according to Wissink. If it’s bad, look out below.

AT&T (T) hasn’t had any double-digit percent moves on earnings recently. But it has gained or lost more than 3% each report—mostly lost—for nine straight quarters. That makes its Oct. 23 report a must-see. The shares look cheap, and a 5.4% dividend yield adds appeal. The phone business is strong. The problem is DirecTV. To young consumers, parabolic TV dishes might as well be media outhouses. If management can at least slow DirecTV cancellations as it shifts to streaming, added confidence in the dividend alone could send the stock higher.

Retail reports won’t pick up until November. Last quarter, Macy’s (M) flopped and Target (TGT) soared. This time around, investors should watch Gap (GPS), especially its Old Navy chain. Old Navy has high overlap in its store locations with Forever 21, which has filed for bankruptcy protection and is closing stores. Over the long term, that puts market share up for grabs, but in the near term, it creates a glut of deeply discounted clothing for sale. Look for commentary on that from management during the earnings call. Gap has announced plans to spin off Old Navy, but results there have been weak of late. Gap shares haven’t moved less than 4% on earnings over the past eight quarters.

Alphabet (GOOGL) has had two big moves on earnings this year—a 7% drop in April after revenue growth slowed to 17%, and a 10% gain in July after growth picked back up to 19%. Which will the third-quarter report resemble in late October? A recent rise in revenue estimates bodes well. So does the fact that analysts are still finding billions of dollars in the company’s couch cushions. Mark Mahaney at RBC Capital Markets took a detailed look at Google Maps in September, and called it one of the greatest under-monetized platforms on the internet. Alphabet could pull a fresh $1.9 billion to $3.6 billion in revenue from it by 2021.

Shares of Alphabet trade at 22 times next year’s projected free cash flow—cheap enough, with or without the Maps money.

Write to Jack Hough at jack.hough@barrons.com
description: Earnings season could generate big moves—up or down—in shares of Netflix, Hasbro, Mattel, AT&T, and Gap.
